text:
A heartening and clue-filled post about developing Excalidraw, a tool for making handdrawn-like diagrams (which works wonderfully on mobile, too)

<https://blog.excalidraw.com/one-year-of-excalidraw/|https://blog.excalidraw.com/one-year-of-excalidraw/>

Sharing mainly for the tools mentioned, but also the great collaborative vibe

attachments.title: One Year of Excalidraw | Excalidraw Blog
attachments.text: It’s been kind of a different year, but it was the first year and pretty amazing for Excalidraw.
attachments.fallback: One Year of Excalidraw | Excalidraw Blog

elements.text: A heartening and clue-filled post about developing Excalidraw, a tool for making handdrawn-like diagrams (which works wonderfully on mobile, too)
Sharing mainly for the tools mentioned, but also the great collaborative vibe

text: Tim, you might want to have a look at what Richard Pawson did for the Irish government. See for example <https://www.infoq.com/presentations/Large-scale-Pure-OO-Irish-Government/?itm_source=presentations_about_Naked_Objects&itm_medium=link&itm_campaign=Naked_Objects|https://www.infoq.com/presentations/Large-scale-Pure-OO-Irish-Government/?itm_sourc[…]about_Naked_Objects&itm_medium=link&itm_campaign=Naked_Objects>. It is a completely different way of looking at the automation (you're not automating the process, your automating the tools to allow people to do their work). I'm really a big fan of Richard's work. Don't let the awkward naming or weird user interface fool you. The power is having tools that help people instead of hinder them (because of fixed processes, rigid rules, etc).

attachments.title: Case Study: Large-scale Pure OO at the Irish Government
attachments.text: Richard Pawson discusses a case study of a large pure OO project for the Irish government, presenting the challenges met, the reason for choosing pure OO, and lessons learned implementing it.
attachments.fallback: InfoQ: Case Study: Large-scale Pure OO at the Irish Government
